be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.data

Class DataProvider

  • java.lang.Object
    • be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.util.Chain<DataProvider>
      • be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.data.DataProvider
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    HazelcastProvider, IgniteProvider, JdbcProvider, LdapProvider, LocalStorageProvider, PlatformConfigurationManager

    public abstract class DataProvider
extends Chain<DataProvider>

    A DataProvider is an abstraction of the blackboard architectural pattern: All communication and synchronisation of Scalar instances and user object happens via one or more DataProvider instances. Conceptually, a DataProvider behaves similar to a map. It stores key-value pairs which can later be retrieved, and allows locking on arbitrary strings (including, but not limited to, the keys of stored values).

    All subclasses of DataProvider that are specified in the configuration file, are instantiated exactly once per Scalar instance (similar to Plugin objects). All DataProvider objects are linked in a chain, in order of occurrence in the configuration file. A DataProvider can check whether there are additional DataProvider instances in the chain via Chain.hasNext(). By default, requests to store values are propagated to all members of the chain. Requests to retrieve data are handled by the first DataProvider that returns an effective value.

    A DataProvider can specify initialisation behavior by overriding the default constructor. Similarly, tasks that should be performed when a DataProvider terminates (i.e., when the Scalar instance terminates), can be specified by overriding terminate().

    Author:
    Thomas Heyman

      • manager

        public Manager manager()

      • get

        public final java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String key)
                           throws DataException
        Attempts to retrieve the value associated to the specified key. If found, it is returned. If not, then the remaining DataProvider instances further up the chain of DataProviders are queried. The first value found will be returned. If no DataProvider has the value corresponding to the specified key, a DataException is thrown. The behavior of retrieving a value from a DataProvider is implemented in getValue(String).
        Parameters:
        key - The key for which a value should be returned.
        Returns:
        The value matching key, stored by this or other DataProvider instances further down the chain (i.e., Chain.next()).
        Throws:
        DataException - When the key is not found in this or Chain.next().

      • getAsString

        public final java.lang.String getAsString(java.lang.String key)
                                   throws DataException
        Helper method that attempts to retrieve the value associated to the specified key as a String.
        Parameters:
        key - The key for which a value should be returned.
        Returns:
        The value matching key, stored by this or other DataProvider instances further down the chain (i.e., Chain.next()).
        Throws:
        DataException - When the key is not found in this or Chain.next(), or when the value is not a String.

      • getAsInt

        public final int getAsInt(java.lang.String key)
                   throws DataException
        Helper method that attempts to retrieve the value associated to the specified key as an int. Note that if a string value is found for key, it will be attempted to parse it as an int (via Integer.parseInt(String)).
        Parameters:
        key - The key for which a value should be returned.
        Returns:
        The value matching key, stored by this or other DataProvider instances further down the chain (i.e., Chain.next()).
        Throws:
        DataException - When the key is not found in this or Chain.next(), or when the value is not an int.

      • getAsDouble

        public final double getAsDouble(java.lang.String key)
                         throws DataException
        Helper method that attempts to retrieve the value associated to the specified key as a double. Note that if a string value is found for key, it will be attempted to parse it as a double (via Double.parseDouble(String)).
        Parameters:
        key - The key for which a value should be returned.
        Returns:
        The value matching key, stored by this or other DataProvider instances further down the chain (i.e., Chain.next()).
        Throws:
        DataException - When the key is not found in this or Chain.next(), or when the value is not a double.

      • getAsBoolean

        public final boolean getAsBoolean(java.lang.String key)
                           throws DataException
        Helper method that attempts to retrieve the value associated to the specified key as a boolean. Note that if a string value is found for key, it will be attempted to parse it as a boolean (via Boolean.parseBoolean(String)).
        Parameters:
        key - The key for which a value should be returned.
        Returns:
        The value matching key, stored by this or other DataProvider instances further down the chain (i.e., Chain.next()).
        Throws:
        DataException - When the key is not found in this or Chain.next(), or when the value is not a boolean.

      • selectFromList

        public java.lang.String selectFromList(java.lang.String key)
                                throws DataException
        Helper method that attempts to retrieve the value associated to the specified key as a boolean. If the value is a string containing commas (,), these will be interpreted as delimiters. A random part of the string will be returned. If the value does not contain commas, this method behaves as getAsString(String). For instance, given the key-value pair "petNames=Fido,Nyan,Bubba", a call to this method with parameter "petNames" will return "Fido", "Nyan", or "Bubba", each with equal probability.
        Parameters:
        key - The key for which a value should be returned.
        Returns:
        A part of the value matching key, stored by this or other DataProvider instances further down the chain (i.e., Chain.next()). Parts are assumed to be comma delineated.
        Throws:
        DataException - When the key is not found in this or Chain.next(), or when the value is not a boolean.

      • put

        public final void put(java.lang.String key,
                      java.lang.Object value)
               throws DataException
        Stores the key/value pair in the chain of DataProvider instances. The first DataProvider that is able to store the key (canStoreKey(String)), stores the key/value pair.
        Parameters:
        key - The key which can later be used to retrieve the value (via get(String)).
        value - The value to store.
        Throws:
        DataException - If no DataProvider is able to store the key (see canStoreKey(String)).

      • replace

        public final void replace(java.lang.String key,
                          java.lang.Object value)
                   throws DataException
        Replaces the value stored under key in the chain of DataProvider instances with the new value. For each DataProvider instance in the chain, if it contains the key (i.e., key is in keys()), the value will be replaced. Note that this method does not make use of canStoreKey(String), and only check whether the specified key already has a value.
        Parameters:
        key - The key for which the corresponding value should be replaced.
        value - The new value for the key.
        Throws:
        DataException - If the value could not be replaced.

      • lock

        public final void lock(java.lang.String key)
                throws DataException
        Locks the specified key. Note that a DataProvider instance will only try to lock the key (via getLock(String)), if it is able to store a value associated to that key (i.e., if canStoreKey(String) is true for key).
        Parameters:
        key - The key to lock.
        Throws:
        DataException - If no suitable DataProvider is found that is able to lock the key, i.e., for no DataProvider in the chain, canStoreKey(String) is true for key}.

      • unlock

        public final void unlock(java.lang.String key)
                  throws LockException,
                         DataException
        Unlocks the specified key. Note that a DataProvider instance will only try to unlock the key (via getUnlock(String)), if it contains the key (i.e., key is in getAllKeys()).
        Parameters:
        key - The key to unlock.
        Throws:
        DataException - If no suitable DataProvider is found that is able to unlock the key, i.e., for no DataProvider in the chain, key is in getAllKeys().
        LockException

      • keys

        public final java.util.List<java.lang.String> keys()
                                            throws DataException
        Returns a list of all keys for which this and all additional DataProvider instances store values. Be advised that this list can be large and, depending on the nature of the active DataProvider instances, can take a while to retrieve.
        Returns:
        An effective (not null), potentially empty list of keys for which the DataProviders contain values.
        Throws:
        DataException

      • delete

        public final void delete(java.lang.String key)
                  throws DataException
        Deletes the value associated to the specified key from this DataProvider, and from Chain.next() (if Chain.next() exists).
        Parameters:
        key -
        Throws:
        DataException

      • terminate

        public final void terminate()
        This method is called upon termination of the Scalar platform. Specific termination behavior is specified in onTermination().

      • dependencies

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Class<? extends DataProvider>> dependencies()
        Specifies the data provider dependencies that this data provider has, if any. Every dependency is specified as a class in the returned list. The Scalar platform will ensure that one instance of every listed dependency has been instantiated before this data provider is instantiated. If one or more dependencies are missing, a MissingDependencyException will be thrown at instantiation time of this data provider. Note that the order in which the dependencies are specified, is not important. By default, a data provider has no dependencies (i.e., the empty list is returned).
        Specified by:
        dependencies in class Chain<DataProvider>
        Returns:
        A list containing data provider types that denote the other data providers that this data provider depends on.
